awd_titl_txt: DDRIG in DRMS: Exploring the role of existential fear appeals and social attachments in natural hazard risk assessment and behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
Climate change is a worldwide threat for both the individual and humanity more broadly. According to the most recent report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, we have to immediately and rapidly reach net zero carbon emissions to avoid many of the worst effects. Determining how to motivate the public to pursue carbon mitigation will therefore be essential for policy makers. This project studies the value, measured by willingness to pay, placed on climate change mitigation in an experimental setting. In particular this project focuses on the way information about climate change is presented to people (i.e., framing) in the context of social preferences). The research studies how social preferences influence willingness to pay and, further, how an individual’s social preferences influence the impact of framing. 

The framing used in this experiment mirrors one of the real world characteristics of climate change. Developed nations pollute the most per capita, but developing nations are the most exposed to negative effects from climate change. Some participants receive framing emphasizing the risks from climate change to themselves directly, whereas others receive language emphasizing the risk to those in developing nations. The hypothesis is that the former framing may be more motivating to self-regarding individuals, whereas individuals who are more strongly concerned with others' welfare are more motivated by the latter framing. Results from this experiment help to inform policy discussions. The findings, for example, may be useful to policy makers trying to word a referendum. Environmental activists may also find the results helpful in tailoring their messages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the completion of the dissertation “Understanding the Role of Existential Threats and Social Attachments in Natural Hazard Threat Evaluation and Action” supported by the National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant in Decision, Risk and Management Sciences. During the completion of his dissertation, Daniel Pilgreen conducted three experimental surveys, two along the Texas Gulf Coast and one representing a national audience, resulting in responses from over 3,000 individuals.

 

Findings from this research found three novel findings. First, the doom-and-gloom approach to discussing climate change and imminent natural hazards impacts how people decide to react to these hazards. Specifically, warning messages can be tailored to include some of this language to persuade people to act, including individually preparing for the hazard, preparing their communities, and engaging in policy to protect themselves and their community. Importantly, this research found that language that emphasizes death should only be used in specific cases. When the threat is very high, these threats actually negatively impact preparedness behaviors. Therefore, these tailored warnings should only be used in low- to moderate-severity cases. Second, the research conducted for this project identified community attachments, such as feeling a part of a community, having people you can trust in your community, and connections to your community play an important role in threat evaluation. When individuals have strong connections to their community more is at risk during a hurricane than just the individual. Therefore, warning messages can also strategically call on community connections to improve preparedness behavior across the community. Lastly, the final study of this project examined climate inaction. Specifically, the project looked to explore reasons why people continue to discredit climate science and refuse to take action on science. Findings suggest that individuals remove their responsibility for climate change by rationalizing actions through a variety of strategies, including pushing off impacts to the future, blaming other individuals or groups, and appealing to greater loyalties like the economy or political party. These three novel findings add to existing psychological knowledge about climate action and natural hazard threat processing. 

 

Beyond this project's academic and knowledge contributions, the project directly contributed to the development of three undergraduate students. Specifically, the project allowed three students to gain a 5-year ethics in human subject research certificate, develop their research methods skills, and advance stakeholder engagement and research presentation skills. Students were directly involved in the project, from design to presentation to stakeholders. One student presented findings at a national conference, while others contributed to the development of deliverables and presentations. Beyond the national impact, research findings were also presented and published internationally at the International Conference on Environmental Psychology in Aarhus, Denmark. In total, the project directly led to two conference presentations, three open-access databases, and a doctoral dissertation.
